title: A Dad Took Photos of His Naked Toddler for the Doctor. Google Flagged Him as a Criminal.
abstract: Google has an automated tool to detect abusive images of children. But the system can get it wrong, and the consequences are serious.

multimedia.caption: Mark with his son this month.

title: How Pharmacy Work Stopped Being So Great
abstract: Two years of economic recovery brought strong gains to workers at the top and the bottom, but headwinds for those in between. Consider the pharmacist.

title: ‘Cable Cowboy’ John Malone Sees More Streaming Bundles Ahead
abstract: The media mogul also said news channels should do a better job of distinguishing between news and opinion.

multimedia.caption: John Malone in 2016. He sits atop an empire with interests in TV, film, live music and professional sports.
John Malone in 2016. He sits atop an empire with interests in TV, film, live music and professional sports.

title: Some Colleges Don’t Produce Big Earners. Are They Worth It?
abstract: Many attendees aren’t better off financially than those who have only a high school degree, at least not right away. How should applicants consider these institutions?

title: How the Find My App Became an Accidental Friendship Fixture
abstract: Introduced 10 years ago, the app has slowly become a popular way to keep track of friends. But it comes with considerable privacy concerns.

title: The Fried Chicken Inflation Index
abstract: YouTube star Elijah Quashie, of the U.K. hit “The Pengest Munch,” copes with the rising cost of wings.

multimedia.caption: Mr. Quashie says prices have roughly doubled since he started his show, with a huge leap at the start of the pandemic.

title: UPS Drivers Say ‘Brutal’ Heat Is Endangering Their Lives
abstract: As summers have grown hotter, high temperatures inside trucks without air conditioning have also sickened postal carriers and others who deliver America’s packages. A few have died.

multimedia.caption: Matt Leichenger, 26, a driver with UPS, delivering packages along his route in Brooklyn Tuesday.

title: TikTok Browser Can Track Users’ Keystrokes, According to New Research
abstract: In the web browser used within the TikTok app, supplementary code lets the company track every character typed by users. The company said the capability was for troubleshooting.
byline: By Paul Mozur, Ryan Mac and Chang Che

multimedia.caption: TikTok, the Chinese-owned app, has faced scrutiny in Washington over its data practices.
TikTok, the Chinese-owned app, has faced scrutiny in Washington over its data practices.
TikTok, the Chinese-owned app, has faced scrutiny in Washington over its data practices.

title: Chief of Israeli Spyware Firm NSO to Step Down as It Revamps
abstract: The U.S. blacklisted the company last year after reports that governments had used its software to target journalists, dissidents and opposition politicians.

multimedia.caption: A branch of the technology company NSO near the southern Israeli town Sapir.
A branch of the technology company NSO near the southern Israeli town Sapir.
A branch of the technology company NSO near the southern Israeli town Sapir.

title: Coming Soon to an American Cliff Near You: ‘Via Ferrata’ Routes
abstract: Long popular in Europe, the beginner-friendly climbing routes are being installed on peaks and in gorges across the United States. Here are six to try now.

multimedia.caption: A group of climbers on a route at Tahoe Via Ferrata.
A group of climbers on a route at Tahoe Via Ferrata.
A group of climbers on a route at Tahoe Via Ferrata.

title: Expansion of Clean Energy Loans Is ‘Sleeping Giant’ of Climate Bill
abstract: The bill President Biden signed into law recently will greatly expand government loans and loan guarantees for clean energy and automotive projects and businesses.

multimedia.caption: The John Day Dam, a hydropower dam in Washington State. The new loan money could spur development of clean energy sources, like converting dams into power facilities.

title: How Quitting a Job Changed My Personal Finances
abstract: We asked people who quit their jobs during the “Great Resignation” what sort of financial challenges it brought. This is what they told us.

multimedia.caption: Rachel Sobel, 52, left her job as the director of communications for a health insurance company in February. Since then she has had more time to enjoy her hobbies, including gardening — but even some necessary expenses have been put on hold.
multimedia.copyright: Evan Jenkins for The New York Times

title: Drought Hurts China’s Economy as Central Bank Cuts Rates
abstract: Sichuan’s many dams cannot generate enough electricity even for its  own needs, forcing factories there to close for up to a week at a time.

multimedia.caption: The dried-out riverbed of a tributary of the Yangtze River, in Chongqing, China, on Sunday.
The dried-out riverbed of a tributary of the Yangtze River, in Chongqing, China, on Sunday.

title: More Than ‘Weird’: Roku Embraces Original Programming
abstract: The streaming media device company wants to attract more viewers and advertisers to its channel. A coming biopic of “Weird Al” Yankovic is its most ambitious project to date.

multimedia.caption: Quinta Brunson as Oprah Winfrey and Daniel Radcliffe as “Weird Al” Yankovic in “Weird,” which will be available on Roku in November.
Quinta Brunson as Oprah Winfrey and Daniel Radcliffe as “Weird Al” Yankovic in “Weird,” which will be available on Roku in November.

title: Live Performance Is Back. But Audiences Have Been Slow to Return.
abstract: Attendance lagged in the comeback season, as the challenges posed by the coronavirus persisted. Presenters hope it was just a blip.
byline: By Michael Paulson and Javier C. Hernández

multimedia.caption: “It wasn’t a season of opening post-pandemic, but during a pandemic, and of course, attendance was weak,” said Adam Siegel, the managing director of Lincoln Center Theater, a New York nonprofit.
multimedia.copyright: Charlie Rubin for The New York Times

title: U.S. Delegation Visits Taiwan for Trade Talks, Risking China’s Ire
abstract: Gov. Eric J. Holcomb of Indiana led a group that arrived on the island Sunday, even as visits this month by U.S. officials have angered Beijing.
byline: By Isabella Kwai and Amy Chang Chien

multimedia.caption: Gov. Eric J. Holcomb of Indiana and his delegation will meet with President Tsai Ing-wen of Taiwan and representatives of the island’s semiconductor industries during a four-day visit.
Gov. Eric J. Holcomb of Indiana and his delegation will meet with President Tsai Ing-wen of Taiwan and representatives of the island’s semiconductor industries during a four-day visit.

title: The Week in Business: WeWork’s Founder Rises Again
abstract: Inflation in Britain picked up. Peloton, a pandemic darling, reports its latest earnings and they’re not expected to be good. The Fed chair will give his take on the economy.

title: HBO Max Pulls Nearly 200 ‘Sesame Street’ Episodes
abstract: HBO Max took down classic episodes of “Sesame Street” as it prepares to combine with Discovery+. The move came as a surprise to fans, who worried about what it signals.

title: Our Prices Are Going Up, but We’re in This Together
abstract: As brands grapple with inflation, a new playbook has emerged: Be upfront about price increases, and hope that transparency will keep customers loyal.

title: Lettuce on Wendy’s Sandwiches Potentially Linked to E. Coli Outbreak
abstract: Federal health officials said that while 37 people had been sickened and 10 hospitalized, it was safe to eat at the fast-food chain and to buy romaine lettuce.

multimedia.caption: Romaine lettuce used on Wendy’s sandwiches is being investigated as a possible cause of dozens of E. coli cases in at least three states.
Romaine lettuce used on Wendy’s sandwiches is being investigated as a possible cause of dozens of E. coli cases in at least three states.

title: Florida Utility Is Fined $500,000 for 2017 Explosion That Killed 5
abstract: Tampa Electric Company pleaded guilty in May to “willfully” violating an OSHA rule that required workers to receive a pre-job briefing about the work they were to perform.

title: Twitter Tells Employees They Might Get Only Half Their Annual Bonus
abstract: The company blamed its financial performance for the potential bonus cut.
byline: By Kate Conger and Ryan Mac

multimedia.caption: Twitter, which is in the middle of a legal battle with Elon Musk, reported a decline in revenue for the first time since 2020 in its earnings report last month.

title: After Signing Climate Bill, Biden Prepares More Actions to Cut Emissions
abstract: Regulations from the E.P.A. and elsewhere will help the president meet his aggressive climate goals, administration officials say.
byline: By Lisa Friedman and Jim Tankersley

multimedia.caption: President Biden may deploy a series of regulatory measures, including new regulations on emissions from a variety of industries, even after signing the Inflation Reduction Act.
President Biden may deploy a series of regulatory measures, including new regulations on emissions from a variety of industries, even after signing the Inflation Reduction Act.

title: Berkshire Hathaway cleared to buy up to 50% of Occidental Petroleum.
abstract: The Federal Energy Regulatory Commission approved a request from Warren Buffett’s company to take a bigger stake in the oil company.

multimedia.caption: Federal regulators have authorized Berkshire Hathaway to acquire up to 50 percent of Occidental Petroleum.
Federal regulators have authorized Berkshire Hathaway to acquire up to 50 percent of Occidental Petroleum.

title: Wayfair will lay off 870 workers after a drop in sales.
abstract: The online furniture retailer boomed in the early months of the pandemic, but it has failed to maintain that momentum.

title: Meme stocks are back. Here’s why wild trading may be here to stay.
abstract: Turbulent trading in shares of companies like AMC Entertainment and Bed Bath & Beyond can no longer be explained as simply a pandemic phenomenon, experts say.
byline: By Joe Rennison and Stephen Gandel

multimedia.caption: Even as pandemic restrictions have lifted, meme stocks continue to draw attention.
Even as pandemic restrictions have lifted, meme stocks continue to draw attention.

title: Retailers Stumble Adjusting to More Selective Shoppers
abstract: In earnings reports this week, companies showed it has been a struggle to adapt to a consumer mind-set that is vastly different from what it was during much of the pandemic.

title: Walmart Expands Employee Abortion Coverage and Will Include Travel Expenses
abstract: The Arkansas-based retailer, the country’s largest employer, said its health plans would cover abortions in specific cases and related travel expenses.

abstract: Electric vehicle batteries are composed of hundreds or thousands of individual lithium-ion cells or pouches.

title: A Trial Put Publishing’s Inner Workings on Display. What Did We Learn?
abstract: The book world can be opaque to outsiders. A case offered an unusual glimpse into it, revealing curiosities about the business and details about book deals.
byline: By Elizabeth A. Harris, Alexandra Alter and Adam Bednar

multimedia.caption: A case involving the proposed merger of Penguin Random House and Simon & Schuster wraps up on Friday. A decision is expected in the fall.
A case involving the proposed merger of Penguin Random House and Simon & Schuster wraps up on Friday. A decision is expected in the fall.

title: Junk Bonds Stage a Comeback as Investors Regain Risk Appetite
abstract: Borrowing by the riskiest companies was higher this week than in all of July, but some warn that the window may not be open for long.

multimedia.caption: Companies have issued $4.1 billion of so-called junk bonds in the United States so far this week, taking advantage of rising investor optimism.

title: Think the Economy Is Hard to Predict? Try the Midterms.
abstract: The overturning of political norms is testing the limits of an established and generally dependable forecasting model that relies solely on economics.

title: Florida’s ‘Stop WOKE’ Act Gets Pushback in Court
abstract: A federal judge blocked a key provision of the state’s law aimed at private businesses, calling it something you might find in an alternate universe.
byline: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Vivian Giang, Stephen Gandel, Lauren Hirsch, Ephrat Livni and Jenny Gross

multimedia.caption: Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida signed the Individual Freedoms Act this year.
